pullRequest.body:
Introduce divisors on subsets of nontrivially normed fields. These are standard book-keeping devices used to keep track of pole/vanishing orders of meromorphic objects, such as functions, differential forms or sections in line bundles. Establish that divisors form a lattice-ordered commutative group. The construction that attaches a divisor to a meromorphic or analytic function will come in a follow-up PR.

Divisors are used in [Project VD](https://github.com/kebekus/ProjectVD), which aims to formalize Value Distribution Theory for meromorphic functions on the complex plane.

@jcommelin Please advise.

I finally had some time to look into this. Here is a diff that sets up the basics so that `.toFun` should never have to appear in the source code or the goal view after the first 20 lines or so.
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/compare/kebekus/divisor...jmc-divisor?expand=1

It also includes a few other minor adaptations which I should have made in separate comments...
@jcommelin Thanks for taking the time! Honestly, I do not really understand these changes, but I merge on the general assumption that you know what you are doing. Thanks again!

I would prefer `support D` or `D.support` over `D.toFun.support`.

Idem dito for `Neg` and `SMul`.
Implemented.
This lemma should make use of the function coercion that you defined upstairs.

I am not sure I understand. If I delete the `.toFun` then I get a different statement that no longer speaks about functions but about divisors. This renders the simp-lemma moot. I think I need to tell the compiler that I want functions ... either by using `.toFun` or by typecasting (D :   )`. 

@jcommelin Please advise.
Sorry for being terse, but indeed, please state it using typecasting.

@jcommelin Thanks for coming back to this. I guess I still need your help. I tried replacing the lemma by
```
lemma add_fun {D D : DivisorOn U} : ((D + D) :   ) =  (D :   ) +  (D :   ) := by rfl
```
This compiles fine, but then many of the `simp`s further down in the file fail. If I move the cursor to the `by`, I can see in the infoview that lean interprets the lemma `add_fun` as
```
 : Type u_1
inst : NontriviallyNormedField 
U : Set 
D D : DivisorOn U
 D.toFun + D.toFun = D.toFun + D.toFun
```
which is definitely not what I wanted to state and what the simplifier needs.

Please advise.
I think `((D + D) :   )` on the LHS should tell Lean to coerce at the correct moment.
@jcommelin Now that works. Thanks! I updated the file accordingly, here and elsewhere.

Maybe for the definition of `Divisor` the `` is a topological space is enough. In this way we can use it in algebraic geometry.

Also, maybe your `Divisor` should be called `DivisorOn`? And `Divisor` just means `DivisorOn univ`.
@acmepjz Thank you for looking at my PR. Let me answer your two proposals separately.
Proposal 2: Implemented as you suggested.

Proposal 1: I am hesitant. Please let me explain why, and what I think could be done instead.

It is correct that the current definition will work with arbitrary topological spaces instead of . However, divisors are used in complex and algebraic geometry to track the vanishing and pole orders of meromorphic functions defined on vector spaces (and, more generally, complex manifolds or algebraic varieties). This is the first PR in a long series; it does not mention the word "meromorphic" anywhere. The follow-up PRs will definitively use the normed field structure of .

You have suggested on Zulip that one might introduce a notion of functions with "locally of finite support" as a generalization to `Finsupp`, and then specialize by saying that divisors are functions of locally finite support where the domain is   and the target is . This might be a viable option if the community has sufficient interest in adding this. Do you think we should ask on Zulip people are interested in having functions of locally finite support?

@jcommelin Do you have any opinion here?

But it's harmless in this file only requiring  be a topological space (by this way your definition can also be used, at least for Riemann surfaces); in later applications you can always plug a normed field into it.

I think most definitions in mathlib try to be as general as possible (although not always make sense in mathematics), for example [Algebra.IsSeparable](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/Separable.html#Algebra.IsSeparable), it said that

> We define this for general (commutative) rings and only assume F and K are fields if this is needed for a proof.

So I think it's same for your `Divisor`.

It doesn't hurt to weaken the assumption in the definition. That way it could in principle be reused in some other specific cases like Riemann surfaces.
Of course we will need a separate definition for divisors on general varieties/schemes for dimension reasons.

> You have suggested on Zulip that one might introduce a notion of functions with "locally of finite support" as a generalization to Finsupp, and then specialize by saying that divisors are functions of locally finite support where the domain is  and the target is . This might be a viable option if the community has sufficient interest in adding this. Do you think we should ask on Zulip people are interested in having functions of locally finite support?

Although this is a viable generalization, I think we should have more use cases beyond just advisors to justify the effort of setting up this definition and the accompanying API.
OK that's subtle. I'll wait other maintainer's opinion.
Roger. Thank you for your understanding!

@kebekus to explain the main aspect of the changes  I made, note that these fields now have a different name: I added a `'` to them. Reason: they explicitly mention `toFun`, instead of the coercion.

[continued below in another remark]
Roger, for this and for the next comments. Thanks!

Here we state the fields of the structure again, with the original names, but the statement now uses the coercion, instead of `toFun`.
So, when using these lemmas, `toFun` doesn't suddenly appear in the goal state.

I think only these 2 result uses normed field condition. The remaining results work on arbitrary topological spaces. 
So I think they should indeed be generalized.

Also, do these 2 results have generalizations on Riemann surfaces?

After random Google search, I found that there is a book *Value Distribution Theory* by L Sario with introducion

> The purpose of this research monograph is to build up a modern value distribution theory for complex analytic mappings between abstract Riemann surfaces

So it should have a definition on them?

@acmepjz Should we have more general definitions? Ideally, I think we should introduce complex spaces following Grauert and define Weil- and Cartier-divisors on those spaces. Once done, one can then show that in the simplest examples, these definitions agree with what we have here.

> I think we should introduce complex spaces following Grauert

Maybe that's far away from now...
It is. The material required fills several books
Can you test that `Add` instances, etc., work for `Divisor`? If not, then this need to be `abbrev Divisor ...`.
I believe this works, even with the latest changes by Commelin.

    s  codiscreteWithin U   z  U,  t  [] z, t  (U \ s) =  := by
  simp only [mem_codiscreteWithin, disjoint_principal_right]
  refine fun h z hz  (U \ s), h z hz, by simp, fun h z hz  ?_
  rw [ exists_mem_subset_iff]
  obtain t, ht, ht := h z hz

```

```

Since there currently no theory about these definitions, I think it is better to postpone them to a later PR.

One trivial thing that I think will be good to add is `DivisorOn.single`, which is takes an `n : Int` and an `x` in `U`, and builds the divisor `n[x]`. Because once you have that, it will be easy to build arbitrary finitely-supported divisors using linear combinations.
But again, this can be done in a follow-up PR.
Roger. I will remove this material for now and re-submit it once I get closer to formulating Nevanlinna's first main theorem. Ditto for the `DivisorOn.single` that you suggest.
